Best cycling shorts with pockets 2023: Buyer’s guide to cargo bib shorts

Bib shorts with pockets have been growing in popularity with the rise of gravel riding, but cargo bottoms aren’t just useful for those riding off the beaten track. Although almost all modern jerseys have pockets at the rear, bib short leg pockets offer easier access, for quick essentials, as well as added storage while riding. Curious about cargo? What are cargo bib shorts?

Cargo bib shorts are, quite simply, bib shorts with pockets. There will typically be a pocket on each leg, and often pockets on the lower back as well. The leg pockets are ideal for easy access to items you want to reach on-the-go, such as snacks or your phone, while the rear pockets tend to be for less regularly needed items, like multitools.

Some brands deploy large rear pockets to store extra layers, which can be easier to use than stuffing them into a small jersey pocket.

Bib short pockets offer an alternative to the traditional jersey pocket, giving riders the opportunity to where a technical T-shirt or ‘regular’ clothing. They are also helpful for those with mobility issues or who struggle with numb hands, as they are easier to access. Unless you’re worried about race-level aerodynamics, there are few downsides to a few extra pockets.

How do we test and why trust our advice?

We do our fair share of kit testing here at Cyclist. We know the struggles of tiny jersey pockets or an ill-fitting chamois, and we know what to look out for when it comes to cycling clothing.

All of the items of this list have been individually tested by our female writers, logging many hours on and off the bike to ensure that we are confident in each product’s performance. Led by tech editor Sam Challis and web editor Matthew Loveridge, our team have put these bib shorts through their paces to give you our honest opinion on their strengths and weaknesses.

Best cargo bib shorts

1. Castelli Unlimited cargo bib shorts

RRP: £135
Highlights: Great break feature on women’s version, Pockets, Quality chamois, Price
Sizes available: XS – XL Colours available: Black, Gunmetal grey

The Castelli Unlimited cargo bib shorts are one of our two pocket bib shorts. The bib shorts have two leg pockets for easy-access storage, which have a top flap to keep contents secure, as well as a thick long distance-focussed chamois.

There is also a comfort break feature. The cross strap design is highly elasticated and pulls down easily, while the overall fit is high-waisted and very comfortable. Though designed for gravel/adventure riding, these are our go-to bib shorts for any riding over an hour.

2. Petrichor Projects women’s bib shorts

RRP: £149
Highlights: Clever comfort break design, Pocket, Comfortable chamois, Smooth, flattering fabric
Sizes available: XXS – XXXL Colours available: Black

The Petrichor Projects bib shorts are up there with the Castellis for comfort, though function quite differently. There is only one pocket so is definitely cargo-lite, but their fit and practicality sit them right up there among the more storage-focussed bibs.

There is a comfort break feature, which uses a magnetic clasp on one of the straps and detaches to allow the rear panel to be dropped. The strap has an added loop which allows you to locate and reconnect it easily.

They have an excellent chamois and get bonus points for being a small, woman-owned independent brand.

3. Albion ABR1 pocket bib shorts

RRP: £145
Highlights: Comfortable cut, Highly stretchy, Effective comfort break design, Great pockets
Sizes available: XS – XL Colours available: Black

The Albion ABR1 bib shorts are fully designed for long-distance riding, with a rear pocket for storing jackets or layers and two side pockets for on-the-go essentials. These have some of our favourite pockets, as they are highly stretchy and deep, and the main body fabric is incredibly soft on the skin.

The comfort break feature features wide, secure bib straps, while the lower panel stretches effectively to provide a simple yet effective comfort break feature. They are also made largely from recycled materials, which is a plus.

The main fabric has a compressive fit, providing a comfortable fit, while the chamois is generous and dense, ideal for long days in the saddle.

5. Endura women’s GV500 Reiver bib shorts

RRP: £139.99
Highlights: Excellent comfort break feature, Supportive chamois, Pockets, Soft fabric
Sizes available: XS – XL Colours available: Black

The Endura GV500 bib shorts feature two mesh leg pockets and, while there is no rear storage, this allows space for one of our favourite comfort break features. The design uses straps that connect at the upper back and split again, which stops the straps sliding on the shoulders – without the need for a cross strap design – and still holds the fabric secure when the feature is not in use.

The chamois is high density and provides effective support on long rides, and there are leg pockets for storage – worth noting that these sit on the front of the leg rather than the traditional side placement. The GV500 bib shorts do run pretty small so we’d recommend sizing up at least one size.

FAQs

What are the benefits of pockets on bib shorts?

The most universal benefit to having bib shorts with pockets is simply extra storage. This can either free you of the need to wear a jersey to carry your belongings, or give you extra space if you’ve got a lot of things to take. This is ideal on long rides where you need lots of fuel, especially if you don’t want to use bike bags.

Cargo pockets are also largely easier to access than traditional jersey pockets, which is useful for those who struggle with mobility or hand numbness. It means less struggle to get to your belongings which is a win all-round for accessibility.

If you aren’t worried about being as aero as possible all of the time – i.e. basically anyone who isn’t actually racing – there are few downsides to having bib shorts with pockets. They’re handy when you need them and can sit empty with basically no added weight when you don’t.

What to look out for in cargo bib shorts

We are big fans of cargo bib shorts but know that, for many, this can be unfamiliar territory so we’ve put together a list of some things to look out for when buying your first pair.

  • Number of pockets – while two leg pockets generally come as standard on cargo bib shorts, it’s worth considering how much extra storage you want. Some bib shorts forgo a comfort break feature in favour of rear pockets so it’s important to decide which is more important to you.
  • Size of pockets – if you’ve got a tiny Nokia brick then maybe this isn’t an issue for you but, for most of us, it’s key to consider if valuables like your smartphone will fit in a cargo pocket. Pockets vary in depth and width so make sure to check this out ahead of time rather than finding out at the start of your first ride.
  • Pocket placement – leg pockets typically sit on the side of the rider’s leg however this is not a set rule. Some place them on the front, some are higher, some are lower etc. Take into consideration your riding position – how aggressive or relaxed it is for example – when deciding which placement will work best for you.
  • Pocket material – the default pocket material is some form of mesh, which is elasticated but durable, though some brands opt to use the same fabric as on the body. There is no right or wrong answer, more so that it is important to check the security of the pocket. If the material is too stretchy, the contents are likely to move about as you ride which can be irksome or even allow objects to fall out.
